homeric-1-s1-91.full_sentence: Apart from Demeter, lady of the golden sword and glorious fruits, she was playing with the deep-bosomed daughters of Oceanus and gathering flowers over a soft meadow, roses and crocuses and beautiful violets, irises also and hyacinths and the narcissus, which Earth made to grow at the will of Zeus and to please the Host of Many, to be a snare for the bloom-like girl â a marvellous, radiant flower.

homeric-1-s2-52.full_sentence: It was a thing of awe whether for deathless gods or mortal men to see: from its root grew a hundred blooms and it smelled most sweetly, so that all wide heaven above and the whole earth and the sea's salt swell laughed for joy.

homeric-1-s6-47.full_sentence: But no one, either of the deathless gods or of mortal men, heard her voice, nor yet the olive-trees bearing rich fruit: only tender-hearted Hecate, bright-coiffed, the daughter of Persaeus, heard the girl from her cave, and the lord Helios, Hyperion's bright son, as she cried to her father, the Son of Cronos.

homeric-1-s13-211.full_sentence: But when the tenth enlightening dawn had come, Hecate, with a torch in her hands, met her, and spoke to her and told her news: 'Queenly Demeter, bringer of seasons and giver of good gifts, what god of heaven or what mortal man has rapt away Persephone and pierced with sorrow your dear heart? For I heard her voice, yet saw not with my eyes who it was. But I tell you truly and shortly all I know.' So, then, said Hecate.

homeric-1-s15-561.full_sentence: So they came to Helios, who is watchman of both gods and men, and stood in front of his horses: and the bright goddess enquired of him: 'Helios, do you at least regard me, goddess as I am, if ever by word or deed of mine I have cheered your heart and spirit. Through the fruitless air I heard the thrilling cry of my daughter whom I bare, sweet scion of my body and lovely in form, as of one seized violently; though with my eyes I saw nothing. But you â for with your beams you look down from the bright upper air over all the earth and sea â tell me truly of my dear child, if you have seen her anywhere, what god or mortal man has violently seized her against her will and mine, and so made off.' So said she.

homeric-1-s23-911.full_sentence: And she, that queen among goddesses answered them saying: 'Hail, dear children, whosoever you are of woman-kind. I will tell you my story; for it is not unseemly that I should tell you truly what you ask. Doso is my name, for my stately mother gave it me. And now I am come from Crete over the sea's wide back â not willingly; but against my liking, by force of strength, pirates brought me thence. Afterwards they put in with their swift craft to Thoricus, and there the women landed on the shore in full throng and the men likewise, and they began to make ready a meal by the stern-cables of the ship. But my heart craved not pleasant food, and I fled secretly across the dark country and escaped my masters, that they should not take me unpurchased across the sea, there to win a price for me. And so I wandered and am come here: and I know not at all what land this is or what people are in it. But may all those who dwell on Olympus give you husbands and birth of children as parents desire, so you take pity on me, maidens, ...'

homeric-2-s11-413.context: lord it among gods and [men] all over the fruitful earth.
homeric-2-s11-413.full_sentence: And Delos rejoiced and answered and said: 'Leto, most glorious daughter of great Coeus, joyfully would I receive your child the far-shooting lord; for it is all too true that I am ill-spoken of among men, whereas thus I should become very greatly honored. But this saying I fear, and I will not hide it from you, Leto. They say that Apollo will be one that is very haughty and will greatly lord it among gods and men all over the fruitful earth. Therefore, I greatly fear in heart and spirit that as soon as he sees the light of the sun, he will scorn this island â for truly I have but a hard, rocky soil â and overturn me and thrust me down with his feet in the depths of the sea; then will the great ocean wash deep above my head for ever, and he will go to another land such as will please him, there to make his temple and wooded groves. So many-footed creatures of the sea will make their lairs in me and black seals their dwellings undisturbed, because I lack people. Yet if you will but dare to swear a great oath, goddess, that here first he will build a glorious temple to be an oracle for men, then let him afterwards make temples and wooded groves amongst all men; for surely he will be greatly renowned.' So said Delos.

homeric-3-s27-43.full_sentence: So the Son of Maia began and said to him: 'Old man, digging about your vines with bowed shoulders, surely you shall have much wine when all these bear fruit, if you obey me and strictly remember not to have seen what you have seen, and not to have heard what you have heard, and to keep silent when nothing of your own is harmed.'

homeric-4-s27-649.context: grant that I may become [a man very eminent among the Trojans] , and give me strong
homeric-4-s27-649.full_sentence: And Anchises was seized with love, and said to her: 'Hail, lady, whoever of the blessed ones you are that are come to this house, whether Artemis, or Leto, or golden Aphrodite, or high-born Themis, or bright-eyed Athena. Or, maybe, you are one of the Graces come hither, who bear the gods company and are called immortal, or else one of the Nymphs who haunt the pleasant woods, or of those who inhabit this lovely mountain and the springs of rivers and grassy meads. I will make you an altar upon a high peak in a far seen place, and will sacrifice rich offerings to you at all seasons. And do you feel kindly towards me and grant that I may become a man very eminent among the Trojans, and give me strong offspring for the time to come. As for my own self, let me live long and happily, seeing the light of the sun, and come to the threshold of old age, a man prosperous among the people.'

homeric-4-s28-409.context: beside my own, for a [Trojan nurse] brought me up at home:
homeric-4-s28-409.full_sentence: Thereupon Aphrodite the daughter of Zeus answered him: 'Anchises, most glorious of all men born on earth, know that I am no goddess: why do you liken me to the deathless ones. Nay, I am but a mortal, and a woman was the mother that bare me. Otreus of famous name is my father, if so be you have heard of him, and he reigns over all Phrygia rich in fortresses. But I know your speech well beside my own, for a Trojan nurse brought me up at home: she took me from my dear mother and reared me thenceforth when I was a little child. So comes it, then, that I well know your tongue also. And now the Slayer of Argus with the golden wand has caught me up from the dance of huntress Artemis, her with the golden arrows. For there were many of us, nymphs and marriageable  maidens, playing together; and an innumerable company encircled us: from these the Slayer of Argus with the golden wand rapt me away. He carried me over many fields of mortal men and over much land untilled and unpossessed, where savage wild-beasts roam through shady coombes, until I thought never again to touch the life-giving earth with my feet. And he said that I should be called the wedded wife of Anchises, and should bear you goodly children. But when he had told and advised me, he, the strong Slayer of Argos, went back to the families of the deathless gods...

orphic-27-s3-26.full_sentence: Of you were born gods and men, you hold sway over the rivers and over all the sea.

orphic-31-s0-49.context: to the sound of arms, [howling mountain men] whose feet pound the ground,
orphic-31-s0-49.full_sentence: Leaping Kouretes, stepping to the sound of arms, howling mountain men whose feet pound the ground, discordant is the lyre you strike as you pace, light of foot, O renowned marshals, O arm-carrying guards, priests in the train of a mother struck with mountain frenzy.

orphic-31-s0-205.full_sentence: Leaping Kouretes, stepping to the sound of arms, howling mountain men whose feet pound the ground, discordant is the lyre you strike as you pace, light of foot, O renowned marshals, O arm-carrying guards, priests in the train of a mother struck with mountain frenzy.

orphic-31-s1-13.context: Kindly visit [the people] who praise you with words,
orphic-31-s1-13.full_sentence: Kindly visit the people who praise you with words, with joyous heart be gracious to the oxherd.

orphic-34-s7-30.context: You have infused harmony into [the lot of all men] , giving them an equal
orphic-34-s7-30.full_sentence: You have infused harmony into the lot of all men, giving them an equal measure of winter and summer: the lowest notes you strike in the winter, the highest notes you make distinct in the summer, your mode is Doric for spring's lovely and blooming season.

orphic-34-s8-12.context: This is why [mortals] call you lord and Pan,
orphic-34-s8-12.full_sentence: This is why mortals call you lord and Pan, the two-horned god who sends the whistling winds; it is for this you have the master seal of the entire cosmos.

orphic-34-s9-43.context: hear the suppliant voice of [the initiates] and save them.
orphic-34-s9-43.full_sentence: O blessed one, hear the suppliant voice of the initiates and save them.

orphic-37-s1-87.full_sentence: From you are descended all toiling mortals, the brood of the sea and of the land, then the brood of the birds, of all generations of the world born of you.

orphic-37-s2-41.context: to banish harsh anger if [some earthly forefather of mine] stormed your homes.
orphic-37-s2-41.full_sentence: I call upon you to banish harsh anger if some earthly forefather of mine stormed your homes.

orphic-41-s0-68.context: of immortal gods and of [mortal men] , weary from searching, weary
orphic-41-s0-68.full_sentence: Queen Antaia, goddess and many-named mother of immortal gods and of mortal men, weary from searching, weary from wandering far and wide, you once ended your fast in the valley of Eleusis, you came to Hades for noble Persephone.

orphic-41-s1-15.context: Your guide was [the innocent child of Dysaules] , who brought the news
orphic-41-s1-15.full_sentence: Your guide was the innocent child of Dysaules, who brought the news of pure Chthonic Zeus' holy union; you bore divine Euboulos by yielding to human need.

orphic-41-s2-79.context: to come graciously to your [pious initiate] .
orphic-41-s2-79.full_sentence: O goddess, O queen to whom many pray, I beseech you to come graciously to your pious initiate.

orphic-43-s3-8.context: Come to [the new initiates] and their holy and reverent
orphic-43-s3-8.full_sentence: Come to the new initiates and their holy and reverent rites, bring perfect seasons for the growth of goodly fruit.

orphic-44-s0-12.context: I call upon [the daughter of Kadmos] , queen of all, fair
orphic-44-s0-12.full_sentence: I call upon the daughter of Kadmos, queen of all, fair Semele of the lovely tresses, of the full bosom, mother of thyrsos-bearing, joyous Dionysos.

orphic-44-s0-50.context: of Kadmos, queen of all, [fair Semele] of the lovely tresses, of
orphic-44-s0-50.full_sentence: I call upon the daughter of Kadmos, queen of all, fair Semele of the lovely tresses, of the full bosom, mother of thyrsos-bearing, joyous Dionysos.

orphic-44-s2-36.context: Noble Persephone granted her honors [among mortal men] , honors given every third
orphic-44-s2-36.full_sentence: Noble Persephone granted her honors among mortal men, honors given every third year.

orphic-44-s3-4.context: For [all mortal men] reenact your travail for your
orphic-44-s3-4.full_sentence: For all mortal men reenact your travail for your son Bacchos: the sacred ritual of the table, the ritual of the holy mysteries.

orphic-45-s2-81.full_sentence: Armed with the thyrsos, wrathful in the extreme, you are honored by all gods and all men who dwell upon the earth.

orphic-50-s2-23.full_sentence: A sorrow-hating joy to mortals, O lovely-haired..., a redeemer and a reveler you are, your thyrsos drives to frenzy, you are kind-hearted to all gods and mortals who see your light.

orphic-50-s2-154.full_sentence: A sorrow-hating joy to mortals, O lovely-haired..., a redeemer and a reveler you are, your thyrsos drives to frenzy, you are kind-hearted to all gods and mortals who see your light.

orphic-51-s5-113.full_sentence: Spring is your joy, O Nysian and frenzied, O healing ones, in the company of Bacchos and Deo, you bring grace to mortals.

orphic-55-s6-80.context: you, where fair maidens and [chaste brides] throughout the year sing of
orphic-55-s6-80.full_sentence: Come lady, even if you are in Kypros that cherishes you, where fair maidens and chaste brides throughout the year sing of you, O blessed one, as they sing of immortal, pure Adonis.

orphic-56-s4-49.full_sentence: Come, O blessed one, bring earth's fruits to the initiates.

orphic-57-s0-86.full_sentence: You dwell on the road all must take, the road of no return, by the Kokytos, you guide the souls of mortals to the nether gloom.

orphic-57-s2-107.context: lead the way for the [everlasting souls of men] .
orphic-57-s2-107.full_sentence: It is to you indeed that Persephone gave the high office throughout broad Tartaros to lead the way for the everlasting souls of men.

orphic-58-s2-23.context: O blessed one, come to [the initiates] with pure thought, banish from
orphic-58-s2-23.full_sentence: O blessed one, come to the initiates with pure thought, banish from them vile impulses.

orphic-59-s0-298.context: in purple, you march toward [men] , whose noble aims match
orphic-59-s0-298.full_sentence: Boundless Fates, dear children of dark Night, hear my prayer, O many-named dwellers on the lake of heaven, where the frozen water is broken by night's warmth in the shady hollow of a sleek cave; from there you fly to the vast earth, home of mortals, from there, clothed in purple, you march toward men, whose noble aims match their vain hopes, in the realm of the dead, where glory drives her chariot on all over the earthbeyond the ends of Justice, of anxious hope, of primeval law, of the measureless principle of order.

orphic-60-s1-100.context: enchanting, come, ever gentle, to [the initiates] to bring them prosperity.
orphic-60-s1-100.full_sentence: We pray that each in her turn with a flower's beauty on her face, enchanting, come, ever gentle, to the initiates to bring them prosperity.

orphic-61-s2-81.context: about the thoughts of all; [the arrogant soul] , the reckless one, finds
orphic-61-s2-81.full_sentence: All who bear the yoke of mortality fear you, you care about the thoughts of all; the arrogant soul, the reckless one, finds no escape.

orphic-61-s2-100.full_sentence: All who bear the yoke of mortality fear you, you care about the thoughts of all; the arrogant soul, the reckless one, finds no escape.

orphic-62-s1-22.full_sentence: From heaven you watch the lives of the many human races, you crush the unjust with just retribution, matching things lawless through the truth of equality.

orphic-62-s2-66.full_sentence: For whenever base opinions prevail in difficult verdicts, because men wish more than is fair, you intervene and rouse justice against her foes.

orphic-63-s0-85.full_sentence: O paragon of justice to mortals, blessed and beloved one, you take equal pleasure in all men who are just.

orphic-63-s3-0.full_sentence: You loath unfairness, but fairness delights you; in you knowledge of virtue reaches its noble goal.

orphic-63-s4-33.full_sentence: Hear, O goddess, rightly shatter wicked men, so that mortals who eat of the fruits of this earth and also all living creatures nursed in the bosom of Earth, the divine mother, nursed in the bosom of sea-dwelling Zeus, may follow a path both balanced and noble.

orphic-64-s3-58.full_sentence: Primeval and wise, in peace he shares the same house with all who abide by the law, bringing harsh vengeance upon the lawless.

orphic-64-s3-114.full_sentence: Primeval and wise, in peace he shares the same house with all who abide by the law, bringing harsh vengeance upon the lawless.

orphic-68-s3-87.full_sentence: Apart from you all is without profit for men: wealth, the sweet giver of abundance for those who feast, fails, and man never reaches the many pains of old age.

orphic-69-s5-5.full_sentence: Upon the races of all men that remain countless, you gaze as the eye of Dike, ever in charge of justice.

orphic-70-s1-5.full_sentence: Over the lives of impious mortals you keep a careful eye, in charge of Necessity, you punish the unjust.

orphic-74-s1-219.context: from wretched death at sea, [men to whom you swiftly come as welcome savior] .
orphic-74-s1-219.full_sentence: Hearken, O goddess, O mistress of the deep-bosomed sea, you delight in waves, you are the greatest savior to mortals, on you depends the unsteady heave of seafaring ships, you alone save men from wretched death at sea, men to whom you swiftly come as welcome savior.

orphic-74-s2-114.context: a fair tail wind to [the initiates] .
orphic-74-s2-114.full_sentence: O divine lady, come to the aid of well-benched ships, do kindly save them, bring upon the sea a fair tail wind to the initiates.

orphic-76-s2-11.context: Do come to [the initiates] , O goddesses, in your
orphic-76-s2-11.full_sentence: Do come to the initiates, O goddesses, in your manifold holiness, do bring glory and emulation that is lovely and sung by many.

orphic-77-s3-23.context: O blessed goddess, for [the initiates] stir the memory of the
orphic-77-s3-23.full_sentence: O blessed goddess, for the initiates stir the memory of the sacred rite, ward off oblivion from them.

orphic-78-s0-47.context: the light of day to [mortals] , resplendent Dawn, you blush
orphic-78-s0-47.full_sentence: Hear, O goddess, you bring the light of day to mortals, resplendent Dawn, you blush throughout the world, messenger of the great, the illustrious Titan.

orphic-78-s1-72.context: the earth when you arrive; [mortal men] you lead to work as
orphic-78-s1-72.full_sentence: Murky, dark, journeying night you send below the earth when you arrive; mortal men you lead to work as you tend to their lives.

orphic-78-s2-0.context: [The race of mortal men] delights in you, no one
orphic-78-s2-0.full_sentence: The race of mortal men delights in you, no one escapes your sight as you look down from on high, when from your eyelids you shake off sweet sleep, when there is joy for every mortal, for every reptile, for animals, for birds, for the broods the sea contains.

orphic-78-s4-53.context: give more sacred light to [the initiates] .
orphic-78-s4-53.full_sentence: Goddess, blessed and pure, give more sacred light to the initiates.

orphic-79-s0-119.context: maiden, the first to show [mortals] the holy oracle as prophetess
orphic-79-s0-119.full_sentence: I call upon pure Themis, daughter of noble Sky and Earth, Themis the young, the lovely-faced maiden, the first to show mortals the holy oracle as prophetess of the gods in her Delphic hideaway on Pythian ground where Python was king.

orphic-84-s1-14.context: May you raise [the holy initiates] in these sacred rites, may
orphic-84-s1-14.full_sentence: May you raise the holy initiates in these sacred rites, may you grant them unwithering youth, wealth as well, prudence and purity.

orphic-85-s0-56.context: of blessed gods and of [mortal men] , of every living thing
orphic-85-s0-56.full_sentence: Sleep, you are lord of all, lord of blessed gods and of mortal men, of every living thing the broad earth nurtures, for you alone are master of all, you do visit all, binding their bodies with fetters unforged.

orphic-85-s2-83.context: be a kindly savior of [the initiates] , that they may serve
orphic-85-s2-83.full_sentence: But, O blessed one, I beseech you to come sweet-tempered, to be a kindly savior of the initiates, that they may serve the gods.

orphic-86-s1-178.context: to show the future to [silent souls] that walk the noble path
orphic-86-s1-178.full_sentence: In the quiet of sweet sleep you come silent, you speak to the soul, you rouse men's minds, in their sleep you whisper the will of the gods; silent you come to show the future to silent souls that walk the noble path of devotion to the gods.

orphic-86-s2-29.context: always wins the race in [people's minds] , good leads their lives
orphic-86-s2-29.full_sentence: Good always wins the race in people's minds, good leads their lives to pleasures anticipated, to a respite from suffering, that god himself may reveal the firmament of the divine lords through vows and sacrifices.

orphic-86-s3-61.context: always so sweeter, but to [the impious] never does a dreamy phantom,
orphic-86-s3-61.full_sentence: The end to which the pious come is always so sweeter, but to the impious never does a dreamy phantom, a prophet of evil deeds, reveal future need so that they may find the cure from pain to come.

orphic-87-s2-67.context: you bring swift end to [youthful life] at its peak.
orphic-87-s2-67.full_sentence: Common to all, you are unjust to some, when you bring swift end to youthful life at its peak.
